264.speaker: Gale
264.text: If I wasn't surrounded on all sides by the darkness of the shadow-cursed lands, I'd think it was Mystra herself brushing against my skin.

388.speaker: Player
388.text: I felt it too. It was like my skin became charged with something. More alive, somehow.

240.speaker: Gale
240.text: That's Mystra's power for you. Where there's even a trace of magic, she will be there to bring it to life.

21.speaker: Gale
21.text: There's clearly some magic in you, if you were able to sense her presence. But I think I felt something stronger.

217.speaker: Gale
217.text: She's left some tiny part of herself to watch over me, I think. A boon to help us reach the Heart of the Absolute in one piece.

298.speaker: Player
298.text: Unless this 'boon' of hers saves you from detonating the orb, it hardly seems worth it.

323.speaker: Gale
323.text: True enough, and somehow I doubt that's an order Mystra will be willing to rescind, no matter how many times I impress her. The stakes are simply too high.

219.speaker: Gale
219.text: Strange, though, that she would reward me for such a service now. She's hardly been forthcoming on that front since my banishment...

105.speaker: Gale
105.text: Perhaps I'm overthinking things. A blessing's a blessing. And this one should come in most useful.

406.speaker: Player
406.text: Ignore her, Gale. She's trying to manipulate you, to convince you to do as she asked.

337.speaker: Gale
337.text: To detonate the orb, you mean?

282.speaker: Gale
282.text: You might be onto something there. Though Mystra's intelligent enough not to resort to such overt manipulation.

223.speaker: Player
223.text: Given all we're up against, I'm grateful for the help.

174.speaker: Gale
174.text: I'd no idea you were so insensitive.
174.context: NodeContext: Joking with them - play on emotional and physical meaning of 'insensitive'

65.speaker: Gale
65.text: No, don't feel disheartened. Very few are capable of attuning themselves to what I just experienced. A state of affairs Mystra prefers, in all honesty.

253.speaker: Player
253.text: She's not speaking to you, Gale. I doubt she's come to give your arm a stroke.

260.speaker: Gale
260.text: Pleasant as that would undoubtedly be, it was no lover's caress I just felt.

341.speaker: Player
341.text: Mystra can't enter the shadow-cursed lands?

394.speaker: Gale
394.text: The curse that afflicts the land appears to be a manifestation of an incredible amount of dark magic - the sort manifested through the Shadow Weave.

148.speaker: Gale
148.text: It is an altogether different form of magic, drawn from the negative spaces left in the Weave's wake. It is Shar's domain, not Mystra's.

97.speaker: Gale
97.text: I'm surprised she would risk making contact here, however briefly.

155.speaker: Player
155.text: Mystra isn't foolish enough to enter the Lady Shar's territory, surely?

43.speaker: Gale
43.text: Mystra and Shar have a rather tense relationship at the best of times. It's best for everyone when they stay out of each others' domains.

115.speaker: Gale
115.text: For her to risk coming here, however tentatively, means she came with good reason. Because of what she asked of me.

272.speaker: Player
272.text: I felt it too. A sensation not dissimilar to the sensation I've known when praying in her holy shrine. Though weaker.

114.speaker: Gale
114.text: Not weak, but subtle. Mystra knows it is a risk to make herself known here, however briefly.

284.speaker: Gale
284.text: After all, this cursed place is not hers but Shar's. Mystra came here with a purpose.

320.speaker: Player
320.text: I felt it too. A sensation not dissimilar to summoning a tendril of the Weave, though weaker.

11.speaker: Gale
11.text: I can't help but feel like I've been fumbling in the dark for too long, and have just had a lit torch thrust into my hands.
11.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale shakes his head gently and chuckles, as if marvelling at something.

53.speaker: Gale
53.text: The crown. The one the elder brain was wearing. The one I very nearly destroyed.
53.context: NodeContext: Building excitement/processing what this could mean

191.speaker: Gale
191.text: Netherese magic. So pure - so complete - that I didn't even recognise it at first...
191.context: NodeContext: Almost dreamy at the memory.

376.speaker: Gale
376.text: The crown. The one the elder brain was wearing.

66.speaker: Gale
66.text: The elder brain. But more importantly, the crown that it wore. Even without seeing it for myself, I could sense it.

108.speaker: Gale
108.text: Netherese magic. So pure - so complete - that I doubted what I was feeling at first.

303.speaker: Gale
303.text: Most Netherese artefacts contain only the faintest amount of their former power - the ghost of an echo of a memory... that crown was different.

404.speaker: Gale
404.text: I can't fathom how such a wonder survived - surely everything of its ilk was destroyed along with Netheril itself... but no matter. It exists, and I must learn more of it.

98.speaker: Player
98.text: Back up a little - why is this crown so important all of a sudden?

259.speaker: Player
259.text: You nearly killed yourself back there. Perhaps take a moment.

56.speaker: Gale
56.text: I know what nearly happened... and I'm sorry, for putting you in that position. But I've stepped back from the precipice now. I've seen what may prove to be another way. A better way.

289.speaker: Gale
289.text: That crown sits on a gargantuan elder brain bent on destroying us and everything we hold dear. Understanding its true nature might unlock the means of our victory.

225.speaker: Gale
225.text: We need to learn more about what we saw. An artefact as powerful as that crown must have been documented somewhere.

254.speaker: Gale
254.text: Sorcerous Sundries is no mere trading post. It's been serving the arcane community for centuries.

208.speaker: Gale
208.text: As luck would have it, we'll soon find ourselves near one of the finest book collections this side of Candlekeep - Sorcerous Sundries. I need to go there, and learn all I can.

203.speaker: Player
203.text: Why would a Baldurian magic shop be the first place we look?

236.speaker: Gale
236.text: Ha! Sorcerous Sundries is no mere trading post. It's been serving the arcane community for centuries.

349.speaker: Player
349.text: So you just want to go shopping?

200.speaker: Gale
200.text: Their collection of rare tomes is unparallelled. Netherese texts are hardly commonplace, but I'm certain they'll have one or two stashed away.
200.context: NodeContext: Key quest info - Tolna will be added to their quest log. Gale only knows of Tolna by reputation, they've not met. Should sound enthusiastic to match into following line

344.speaker: Gale
344.text: I doubt they'll have any books on breaking contracts with devils, though. We'll have to figure that one out for ourselves.

375.speaker: Gale
375.text: You'll have to forgive my eagerness, but if my suspicions prove to hold water, this could be the answer to all our problems.

4.speaker: Player
4.text: Let's just get to Baldur's Gate, first of all.

271.speaker: Gale
271.text: Indeed, the journey awaits. One foot in front of the other is tried and true, I find.

283.speaker: Gale
283.text: No...? My needs are modest, but the fruits they could be may prove immense. I can only hope you have a change of heart when the time comes.

122.speaker: Gale
122.text: After all, a brief expedition into the bookshelves of Sorcerous Sundries is a small price to pay to save an entire city. Even if you aren't a fan of reading.
122.context: NodeContext: Still hoping you'll agree to this

330.speaker: Player
330.text: I'm not so sure you're owed any favours just now.

266.speaker: Gale
266.text: Likely not. If I've done damage to your opinion of me, then I am truly sorry. But if this crown amounts to what I suspect it is, then your faith will soon be restored, and then some.

408.speaker: Gale
408.text: It's clear crown and brain are intrinsically connected, and given the pressing urgency of us smiting the latter, understanding the former could make all the difference.

269.speaker: Player
269.text: So you're dropping the whole 'blowing yourself up' thing? You think I'll just forget about that?

161.speaker: Player
161.text: So you're dropping the whole 'blowing yourself up' thing? You think I'll just forget about that?

356.speaker: Player
356.text: You seem in a good mood. I thought you might be more subdued after coming close to blowing up.

373.speaker: Gale
373.text: Indeed... under other circumstances, I might have been subdued. Or ashamed. But after what we saw? I must admit I'm excited.

232.speaker: Player
232.text: You don't miss the shadow-cursed lands, then?

243.speaker: Gale
243.text: Hardly - I'm more than glad to leave that place behind.

403.speaker: Player
403.text: We're not out of the shadow-cursed woods yet, Gale...

16.speaker: Gale
16.text: Apologies - I got rather lost in the metaphor there. Allow me to provide a map -

28.speaker: Gale
28.text: I speak of what we discovered at the heart of this cursed place.

32.speaker: Gale
32.text: Back on mortal soil once more. I can't believe I saw her, after all this time...
32.context: NodeContext: Filled with nervous energy - like coming off stage at the end of a performance

275.speaker: Player
275.text: How do you feel now you've done it?

350.speaker: Gale
350.text: Relieved. Drained. Proud of myself, for summoning the courage to go to her in the first place. And, if I'm being totally honest - a bit light-headed.

360.speaker: Gale
360.text: As if it wasn't enough to have seen her again, she didn't exactly summon me there for small talk.

168.speaker: Player
168.text: I'm not surprised. Her power felt overwhelming, even from here.

313.speaker: Gale
313.text: And what you felt was but the slightest drop drawn from the rushing torrent that is the Weave. I confess, without my former prowess even I struggled to stand her presence.

382.speaker: Gale
382.text: The effects on the mortal body of such unfettered magical exposure cannot be overestimated. She held back in order to protect us. To make sure I heard her.

405.speaker: Player
405.text: Yes, I'm sure it was very memorable. But did she tell us anything useful?

150.speaker: Gale
150.text: She gave us the secret of the orb's power. I'd call that extremely useful knowledge to have.

277.speaker: Gale
277.text: The Karsite Weave, within me this whole time...
277.context: NodeContext: Stunned by this revelation, not sure what to make of it

169.speaker: Gale
169.text: I knew the orb was no ordinary ball of magic, but for it to be Karsus' malignant creation... gods, how did I not see that?
169.context: NodeContext: A bit annoyed at himself for missing this - dented his pride

58.speaker: Player
58.text: It's not your fault. You weren't to know.

139.speaker: Gale
139.text: What right had I to go about declaring myself an archmage, when I was as foolish as a common apprentice in setting such an entity loose?

160.speaker: Gale
160.text: At least now I'm armed with the truth. And Mystra's expectations.

106.speaker: Gale
106.text: Once I bring the Crown of Karsus to her, I can put everything right. The orb too. I'll be myself again - for all that's worth.
106.context: NodeContext: Trying to sound positive about this thought, but struggling to overcome how disappointed he is in himself

96.speaker: Gale
96.text: It sounds like the door to redemption is open at last. All I have to do is walk through it, carrying the Crown of Karsus.
96.context: NodeContext: Not sure what he's going to do

358.speaker: Gale
358.text: I see few other options open to me, if I ever want to reclaim those parts of myself the orb snatched away.

299.speaker: Gale
299.text: If I ever want to be me again.

175.speaker: Player
175.text: We're going to cure you - I promise.

138.speaker: Gale
138.text: There aren't many I'd trust to stand beside me on such a journey. Fewer still who would do so because they believe I deserve such a chance.

126.speaker: Player
126.text: You're a great man, Gale. With or without the orb.

280.speaker: Gale
280.text: I'll have to disagree with you there. Having not one but two parasitic entities within your body does very little for one's faith in one's personality.

50.speaker: Gale
50.text: Still, I should take the compliment with the same generosity it was given. So - thank you.

335.speaker: Gale
335.text: If I can promise you one thing in return for your faith in me, it's this - I will use everything in my power to ensure we defeat this evil.

369.speaker: Gale
369.text: I will not let you down.

402.speaker: Gale
402.text: Now, I believe we've a date with an elder brain to get to. Shall we?

239.speaker: Player
239.text: A better incarnation of you, I hope. Not the impulsive wreck who unleashed the orb in the first place.

328.speaker: Gale
328.text: Impulsive wreck? Gods, you make me sound like something a drunk fisherman scuppered on the banks of the Chionthar.

164.speaker: Gale
164.text: Needless to say - I've work ahead of me before I'll feel myself truly redeemed of the damage I caused. But I intend to try.

209.speaker: Player
209.text: And what then? What will you do?

417.speaker: Gale
417.text: I - I don't know. It's been so long since I dared to imagine an end to the orb's hunger. I'd better start thinking about it, hadn't I?
417.context: NodeContext: Realising he doesn't have the answer, stumped

395.speaker: Gale
395.text: Imagine - being able to picture one's life ending in something other than a cataclysmic explosion. What a treat.

432.speaker: Player
432.text: Then we need to take this chance. You deserve to be cured, Gale.

113.speaker: Player
113.text: When you put it like that, it sounds rather easy...

261.speaker: Gale
261.text: Well, what's a ginormous elder brain once you've grappled with your own crippling anxieties?

377.speaker: Gale
377.text: It would be quite something to wake up in the morning without regret, and live each day knowing another will follow, like as not.

397.speaker: Gale
397.text: To be rid of the orb, and perhaps claim back what it took... To be me again.

59.speaker: Player
59.text: I thought you more ambitious than this, Gale. Why settle for mortality when immortality is on the table?

306.speaker: Gale
306.text: I suppose there's no harm continuing to entertain the idea. Quietly.

178.speaker: Player
178.text: Sod redemption. With the Karsite Weave and the Crown, you could be a god.

36.speaker: Gale
36.text: Were I a more superstitious man, I confess I'd be inclined to see a certain divine destiny in the greatest of Karsus' creations re-emerging at the same time as one another, in the same city.

307.speaker: Gale
307.text: What if this is my chance? I'd be a fool not to take it...

316.speaker: Player
316.text: You'd be more of a fool for chasing godhood. Take up Mystra's offer - it's the best way.

82.speaker: Gale
82.text: I suppose you're right. No sense adding the all-powerful goddess of magic to our list of enemies. We've enough of those already.

348.speaker: Gale
348.text: Onwards to redemption then. And whatever lies beyond...

391.speaker: Player
391.text: You're right. This opportunity is too good to pass up. We need to get you that Crown.

57.speaker: Player
57.text: And what then? What if you became a god?

71.speaker: Gale
71.text: The futures unfolding for us would be infinite - impossible for me to describe. But possible for me to show you.

143.speaker: Gale
143.text: Find me at a more... private moment, and I will provide a glimpse into what the Crown could mean. For both of us.

116.speaker: Gale
116.text: I would be everything. No mere archmage, but the embodiment of a new form of magic, raw potential dancing from my fingertips.

274.speaker: Gale
274.text: I would have back everything I lost and a thousand times more. I would get what I deserved, one might argue.

61.speaker: Player
61.text: It's all too easy to miss things when we're blinded by desire.

194.speaker: Gale
194.text: True enough. There's a reason such unwitting heroes have been the backbone of lyric and legend for as long as both have existed.

343.speaker: Gale
343.text: Even so - I was hardly some naive apprentice at the time. I considered myself an archmage, and yet was fool enough to be mistaken for a common conjurer.

119.speaker: Player
119.text: Because you acted the idiot. And paid the price for it too.

374.speaker: Gale
374.text: As always, I endeavour to be invigorated by your candour, rather than eviscerated by it.
374.context: NodeContext: Emotionally flinching at being called an idiot

309.speaker: Gale
309.text: Blunt as your summation is - it's correct. I dared to call myself an archmage while acting the apprentice. The hallmarks of a most excellent idiot, unfortunately.

55.speaker: Gale
55.text: If Mystra were here, I don't think she'd be best pleased with me for doing that.

291.speaker: Gale
291.text: She was always rather fond of pixies.
291.context: NodeContext: Context - Gale mangled the corpe of a pixie in the creation of an evil, shadow-wielding lantern

30.speaker: Gale
30.text: Still, I'm sensing no signs of any divine retribution incoming. I'm not quite sure what to make of that.

418.speaker: Player
418.text: It makes sense. Why punish you when she's already given you a death sentence?

15.speaker: Gale
15.text: True enough. She'd certainly not want to jeopardise the completion of this little mission she and Elminster have concocted.

244.speaker: Gale
244.text: It may not be the most savoury kind of magic, but it will taste sweet enough if it brings us to the Heart of the Absolute in one piece.

296.speaker: Player
296.text: I'm not sure I like you using these dark powers. There's something wrong about them.

338.speaker: Gale
338.text: We're up against the greatest threat Faerûn has ever faced. I don't mind getting my hands dirty if it gives us a better chance of surviving.

193.speaker: Gale
193.text: Refusing to compromise my morals would be rather a selfish thing given how many lives are at stake.

248.speaker: Player
248.text: I love unsavoury things. Don't feel guilty on my account.

300.speaker: Gale
300.text: That's good to know. Although, I should say I do what I do out of a sense of utility and pragmatism, not a love of the unsavoury.

103.speaker: Player
103.text: We'll need all the power we can get if we're to succeed against the Absolute.

428.speaker: Gale
428.text: Whatever advantage I can gain for us, I will. And I refuse to feel guilty for it, no matter how much Mystra's chidings might echo in my skull.

213.speaker: Player
213.text: And beyond it. If Mystra's letting you choose these powers, you have a choice about the orb.

35.speaker: Gale
35.text: Quite the pair of legs you've got on you, to make that kind of leap.

162.speaker: Gale
162.text: No, Mystra wouldn't have issued an order like that if she was content for it to be ignored. She meant it. Perhaps so much so that's she's willing to overlook transgressions like this...

242.speaker: Player
242.text: Be sure you understand what it is to use this kind of magic. It corrupts by its very nature.

133.speaker: Player
133.text: Be sure you understand what it is to use this kind of magic. It corrupts by its very nature.

81.speaker: Gale
81.text: Then thank goodness I have you to keep me in check.
81.context: NodeContext: Bit of side-eye at the player here - they were the ones who either influenced Gale to do this, or followed his advice. A bit hypocritical

293.speaker: Gale
293.text: Now come, we'd best keep moving. We have many more shadows to face before we reach the Heart of the Absolute.

425.speaker: Player
425.text: She wants you to obey her command. She's hardly going to chastise you and put that at risk.

361.speaker: Gale
361.text: A valid and most astutely observed point.

142.speaker: Player
142.text: It means you're free of her, Gale. You don't live by her doctrine any more.

132.speaker: Gale
132.text: It certainly seems that way, doesn't it? And I suspect that suits her rather well for the time being.

412.speaker: Player
412.text: You're in the Lady Shar's territory now. Mystra has no sway here.

23.speaker: Player
23.text: Mystra cannot reach us in this tainted darkness. Your faith must guide you where she cannot.

130.speaker: Gale
130.text: Mystra would certainly exercise caution were she to make her presence felt in these cursed lands. But if she wanted to do so, even Shar couldn't stop her.

67.speaker: Gale
67.text: No, if she's remained silent then it goes without saying that such silence carries import of its own.

315.speaker: Gale
315.text: So long as I have her mission ahead of me, I suspect she'll not want to distract me with any undue moralising.

84.speaker: Gale
84.text: I can't help but feel like I've been fumbling in the dark for too long, and have just had a lit torch thrust into my hands.

127.speaker: Gale
127.text: I hope you're here to discuss that contract you just signed. Agreeing to give away our greatest hope of salvation wasn't the wisest of moves.

14.speaker: Gale
14.text: Tara remains as wilful as ever, but I'm glad you've finally made her acquaintance.

286.speaker: Gale
286.text: Given the length of my time away, I feared she might have given up on me. I should have known better - she'd never do such a thing.

101.speaker: Player
101.text: So, your last name is Dekarios?

13.speaker: Gale
13.text: It is. Courtesy of my mother, the inimitable, dare I say it sometimes unavoidable, Morena Dekarios.

390.speaker: Gale
390.text: It's been so long since I've used it. 'Gale Dekarios' cuts a poor figure next to the wizarding prowess of 'Gale of Waterdeep.'

207.speaker: Player
207.text: Gale Dekarios... I think I like him more.

166.speaker: Gale
166.text: You like so many things about me I'd have sooner discarded... Your generosity is quite wonderful.

426.speaker: Gale
426.text: Gale Dekarios likes you too. Very, very much. Though let's keep his existence between ourselves for now.

340.speaker: Gale
340.text: Oh, she's happy if I'm happy. Morena couldn't care one jot what I call myself. Tara's the real stickler for using it. Has done since I summoned her.

80.speaker: Gale
80.text: I'd prefer you not follow her example, if that's all the same to you. 'Gale' is more than sufficient.

196.speaker: Gale
196.text: Was there anything else you needed of me?

278.speaker: Player
278.text: There was something else on my mind...

251.speaker: Gale
251.text: Anything you ask, I'll answer as honestly as I can. I'm an open book, requiring only your gentle hands to turn my pages.

99.speaker: Gale
99.text: I agree. And on the plus side, if I get myself into any truly cataclysmic straits during the remainder of our journey, my family name will go untarnished.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: That's something Tara and I have in common.

370.speaker: Player
370.text: I can see why you love her. She's quite the character.

359.speaker: Gale
359.text: That's Tara - loyal, intelligent, brave, and apparently unwilling to follow even the most basic of instructions when her own safety is at stake.

211.speaker: Gale
211.text: I wouldn't have her any other way.

227.speaker: Gale
227.text: I'd actually been thinking about introducing the two of you anyway. Over a sumptuous home-cooked meal, if that sounds at all to your taste?
227.context: NodeContext: Slightly nervous - inviting you to come to his house for the first time

381.speaker: Gale
381.text: My tower in Waterdeep boasts an excellent kitchen and a wine cellar to rival Ondal himself. Not to mention a larder stocked with my homemade hundur sauce.
381.context: NodeContext: Pre-emptively trying to convince his partner to come

389.speaker: Gale
389.text: A Waterdhavian delicacy, spiced to leave exactly the right amount of heat lingering on the tongue, and served with that most sharp-toothed of aquarian residents, the quipper fish.

247.speaker: Gale
247.text: I make it to my mother's recipe. It packs quite a wallop. As does she.

270.speaker: Gale
270.context: NodeContext: Genuine, excited in a quite sweet way

76.speaker: Player
76.text: Inviting me to your house for the first time? You must really like me.

212.speaker: Gale
212.text: More than you could possibly believe.

346.speaker: Player
346.text: I'd rather we did something just the two of us. Without the cat...

17.speaker: Gale
17.text: Ah, you have something more private in mind? No - don't tell me. I'll let my imagination fill in the gaps.

128.speaker: Gale
128.text: Now that we've got something to look forward to, I think it's time we went and saved the world. Don't you?

62.speaker: Gale
62.text: I always imagined what it would be like when you finally got to meet her. This wasn't quite what I pictured.
62.context: NodeContext: Slightly nervous - inviting you to come to his house for the first time

201.speaker: Gale
201.text: I thought we'd be in Waterdeep. You, curled up before a roaring hearth while I prepared us a ridiculously extravagant meal, served with a batch of my homemade hundur sauce.

104.speaker: Gale
104.text: I fear mine is a dream for another life. But a fine one nonetheless.

187.speaker: Gale
187.text: As for this one, I think we've still got a world to save. Unless there's anything else?

48.speaker: Gale
48.context: NodeContext: subtext - Gale still intends to blow himself up. He knows he'll never make the date.

339.speaker: Player
339.text: It could still happen. So long as we find another way to beat the Absolute.

158.speaker: Gale
158.text: Gods, I love your optimism. Contagious in the most endearing way.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: Wouldn't you rather imagine something quieter. Just the two of us...

54.speaker: Player
54.text: Seemed a fairly ordinary cat to me.

273.speaker: Gale
273.text: A tressym. Call her a cat again, and I assure you, you'll fare no better in her estimations than she apparently fares in yours.
273.context: NodeContext: Correcting you, potentially already corrected you on this before. Keep it light, this is in the romance path

326.speaker: Gale
326.text: I know you love me. Perhaps it was too much to expect you to love my cat as well. I mean, tressym.
326.context: NodeContext: With a sigh, slightly overdramatic, then realising he's made the same mistake he just corrected in the player.

184.speaker: Player
184.text: She launched a fireball at me, Gale!

144.speaker: Gale
144.text: Oh, I'm sure she had her reasons.
144.context: NodeContext: Pleasant, ignoring Tara's bad behaviour

216.speaker: Gale
216.text: The Absolute should be a thing of the past, and I with it... yet at the risk of angering Mystra further, I'm glad it didn't come to that. Given what has come to light.

268.speaker: Gale
268.text: An audience with Elminster is never less than memorable.
268.context: NodeContext: Pensive, but feigning good cheer just got told he needs to blow himself up. Black humour to it.

45.speaker: Gale
45.text: I suppose it's time we dealt with the hollyphant in the room: you have questions for me, and I promise I have answers.
45.context: NodeContext: Weak humour, he's pretty nervous how you're going to react - Elminster just revealed he's a walking time bomb

234.speaker: Player
234.text: What's this 'orb' Elminster was talking about?

180.speaker: Gale
180.text: Ah. Well, that's rather a long and complicated story.

302.speaker: Player
302.text: You owe me an explanation. Why didn't you tell me the truth?

257.speaker: Gale
257.text: I'm sorry, and I assure you - you were never at risk. However, the cause of my condition is... complicated.

383.speaker: Player
383.text: You think this is funny? All this time, you could have killed me!

409.speaker: Gale
409.text: Not at all. Just some gallows humour for you. I assure you - you were never in any danger. Let me explain.

134.speaker: Player
134.text: I have questions, but not about that.

20.speaker: Gale
20.text: Hint taken. We'll leave that particular fuse unlit, for now. What do you need of me?
20.context: NodeContext: Not quite believing the player is letting this go (learning he's a walking bomb), but happy to go along with it.

427.speaker: Gale
427.text: Oh. Well, in that case, I suppose we'll just move on.

437.speaker: Gale
437.text: I'd have hoped to introduce you to him in less dire circumstances, but those are hard to come by these days.

210.speaker: Player
210.text: I'd always imagined Elminster to be more... imposing.

197.speaker: Gale
197.text: The doddering act is merely an illusion, one he's most adept at maintaining. Elminster is the most formidable wizard in the realms, perhaps in existence.

47.speaker: Player
47.text: An old man with a craving for cheese. Hardly the great wizard of legend.

29.speaker: Gale
29.text: A wizard doesn't reach Elminster's age without enjoying their home comforts. Those who seek danger over cheese don't tend to live as long.
29.context: NodeContext: Bitter humour - he's  the kind who seeks danger, and believes he won't reach Elminster's age

276.speaker: Gale
276.text: For Mystra to have sent him... The severity of her bidding could not be clearer. Or weigh more heavily on me.
276.context: NodeContext: Reflecting on Mystra sending Elminster, of all people - very powerful individual. Becoming reflective.

167.speaker: Gale
167.text: Time seems so infinite when you are young... a month is an age, a year is a lifetime... it is a strange feeling, to realise how little of it one might have left.

396.speaker: Player
396.text: You're seriously considering doing what Elminster said?

416.speaker: Gale
416.text: Of course - he offered the clearest solution to our problem. All I have to do is find the right place and time, close my eyes, and let go...
416.context: NodeContext: Trying to sound upbeat, not fully engaging with what he's saying (that he's going to kill himsef)

124.speaker: Gale
124.text: Then the slate will be clean, wrongs will be righted, the Absolute will be gone...
124.context: NodeContext: Trying to sound upbeat, not fully engaging with what he's saying (that he's going to kill himsef)

93.speaker: Gale
93.context: NodeContext: Still trying to sound upbeat, though at this point the reality that this means he will die weighs a bit heavier

215.speaker: Player
215.text: I don't understand. Can't Mystra just destroy the Absolute? Or Elminster himself?

85.speaker: Gale
85.text: I've no doubt she has the power to do so, but as for the permission... Ao would not look kindly on her meddling in mortal affairs. Divine intervention has a tendency to make things worse, not better.

288.speaker: Gale
288.text: As for Elminster... He's saved the realms more times than legend can recount. But to take on a god is no easy feat, even for him. My orb is the best chance we have - and only I can wield it.
288.context: NodeContext: respectful of Elminster. Gale accepting his grim responsibility

102.speaker: Player
102.text: So that's it? You're on a suicide mission now?

262.speaker: Gale
262.text: Possibly the most spectacular one ever conceived, but essentially, yes.

351.speaker: Gale
351.text: I am living on borrowed time, in more ways than one. Perhaps... perhaps this is how it must be.

327.speaker: Gale
327.text: If there was, I'm sure the goddess of magic and the greatest wizard who ever lived would have identified it, but alas... only one solution is offered.

111.speaker: Player
111.text: What about me? Am I safe around you?

314.speaker: Gale
314.text: That's the one saving grace. It seems the orb is now stable, at least until I get to where I need to be.

149.speaker: Gale
149.text: But that remains ahead of us for now. The Heart of the Absolute must be discovered before I can stop its beating.

112.speaker: Player
112.text: I'll make sure we find it, Gale. I promise.

90.speaker: Gale
90.text: Then I suppose there is nothing more to be done but find the Heart of the Absolute... and stop its beating.
90.context: CinematicNodeContext: Spoken with a nod of resolve  at the beginningNodeContext: Spoken with a nod of resolve  at the beginning

312.speaker: Player
312.text: You're not blowing yourself up, Gale. I won't let you.

38.speaker: Gale
38.text: Let's save such certainty for the moment such a decision is upon us. You may feel differently, once we know what we're truly up against.

379.speaker: Player
379.text: Whatever you need to do, I'll be there to help.

400.speaker: Gale
400.text: I had no doubt I could rely on you.

301.speaker: Player
301.text: I'll leave you to your thoughts.

419.speaker: Gale
419.text: Of course. Kind of you to stop by.

199.speaker: Player
199.text: He didn't seem much a friend, showing up and demanding you kill yourself.

279.speaker: Gale
279.text: It's not a demand he wanted to make of me. As Mystra's Chosen, he had no choice but to deliver her message, however much it pained him to do so.

281.speaker: Player
281.text: He sent instruction from Mystra herself. You would be a brave wizard to refuse her.

371.speaker: Gale
371.text: Brave, or stupid. I've proved myself the latter too many times where she's concerned.

290.speaker: Player
290.text: It was an honour to meet Mystra's Chosen, though his purpose with you was bleak.

235.speaker: Gale
235.text: It certainly wasn't the reunion I was hoping for. Though if anyone had to deliver such a message, I'm glad it was my old friend.

250.speaker: Player
250.text: Actually, I was hoping to talk about something else.

380.speaker: Gale
380.text: No comment on a visit from the finest wizard in the realms, the famed Elminster of legend and lore? You are hard to impress.
380.context: NodeContext: Not snarky - warm, amused by your practicality

131.speaker: Gale
131.text: So, what did you wish to speak about?

329.speaker: Gale
329.text: I can't believe Mystra granted me an audience, and I failed to hear her out.

231.speaker: Gale
231.text: She won't extend that invitation twice. We'll have to figure things out ourselves from here.

424.speaker: Gale
424.text: At least our conversation needn't come to such an abrupt halt. Unless you'd rather it did, of course.

364.speaker: Gale
364.text: You'll have to forgive me, but I'm struggling to understand why you'd agree to just hand over the crown? Especially for a bloody... hammer.
364.context: NodeContext: Almost lost for words, he's so irritated by you

423.speaker: Player
423.text: According to Raphael, that crown destroyed an empire. Imagine what other evil it could do.

109.speaker: Gale
109.text: And handing it over to a devil would be a way to prevent it? Come now - you're many things, but never that naive.
109.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale taps himself on the chest, indicating where the orb lies

230.speaker: Player
230.text: It's a fair trade. The hammer is more valuable to us than the crown - it offers us a chance of survival.

10.speaker: Gale
10.text: Oh, yes of course I can see how the hammer we didn't know existed until Raphael generously enlightened us would take precedence.

319.speaker: Gale
319.text: He's always struck me as the trustworthy type.

224.speaker: Gale
224.text: We already know the potential that Crown possesses. We read it, written in Karsus' own hand.

70.speaker: Gale
70.text: I thought you understood that, but it seems I was mistaken.

354.speaker: Gale
354.text: If you'd rather put such power in the hands of a devil than in me, your trusted companion, well... that companionship might prove a rather fleeting one.

153.speaker: Gale
153.text: For now, our plan must remain the same. We go to Sorcerous Sundries, and learn about that crown. And pray the devil doesn't get there first.

91.speaker: Gale
91.text: I promise you - whatever outcomes we're hoping for in this world-ending endeavour of ours, letting that devil get hold of the crown must not be one of them.

228.speaker: Gale
228.text: No - what we should be pursuing is knowledge. We need to learn more about that crown.

392.speaker: Gale
392.text: We should pay a visit to Sorcerous Sundries. Their book collection is the envy of the Sword Coast - I'm certain the truth lurks somewhere on their shelves.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: Why are you so certain we should pursue the crown?

414.speaker: Gale
414.text: Why are you so certain we shouldn't?

8.speaker: Player
8.text: Don't worry, I said what Raphael wanted to hear. I have no intention of giving him the crown.

287.speaker: Gale
287.text: I'm glad to hear it. But you realise, we can't just tell him we changed our minds.
287.context: NodeContext: Still agitated - the player has still made things very complicated/dangerous

345.speaker: Gale
345.text: You signed an infernal contract, not some half-baked deal on the back of a napkin. If this scheme of yours fails, the Crown of Karsus is Raphael's, whether you 'intended' it or not.
345.context: NodeContext: Annoyed but willing to drop it, for now. 'Intended' with a little extra on it - calling back to the player's phrasing (I have no 'intention' of giving him the crown'.

107.speaker: Gale
107.text: I knew any artefact that could command an elder brain must be close to omnipotent, but for it to be the very crown Karsus forged... it verges on unbelievable.

385.speaker: Gale
385.text: I assure you - the hammer Raphael offered is mere scrap metal in comparison, whatever use he claims for it.

365.speaker: Gale
365.text: So the devil himself is pursuing the crown.

433.speaker: Gale
433.text: As for whether it's truly the Crown Karsus forged? Well, I think it's safe to assume we shouldn't take anything Raphael utters at face value.

353.speaker: Gale
353.text: Nor should we have signed any contracts with him, though that particular ship has already hoisted anchor and set sail with full crew and cargo...
353.context: NodeContext: Slightly passive aggressive - the player just signed the contract against Gale's wishes

135.speaker: Gale
135.text: We must claim the Crown of Karsus for ourselves - before anyone else does.
135.context: NodeContext: Urging, imperative that you do this

179.speaker: Gale
179.text: With that crown, Karsus almost toppled the gods themselves. We cannot hand such power over to Raphael. We must take it for ourselves.

367.speaker: Gale
367.text: Please - this has gone on long enough.

357.speaker: Gale
357.text: I was quite clear about the imperative nature of my request to you, and despite that  I've seen neither hair nor hind of a magic artefact.

68.speaker: Gale
68.text: Already, I fear I've left my hunger untreated for too long. I need a magic artefact - now.

100.speaker: Gale
100.text: Already, I've allowed myself to go untreated for too long. I fear it's already too late - I've no choice but to depart this company of ours, and pray I find something for myself.
100.context: NodeContext: Pissed off but holding back. Leaving the party for good.

147.speaker: Player
147.text: I'm sorry Gale. I hope you find what you're looking for.

434.speaker: Gale
434.context: NodeContext: Pissed off but holding back. Leaving the party for good.

165.speaker: Player
165.text: Don't go, Gale. I'll help you - you have my word.

46.speaker: Gale
46.text: Unless your 'word' is an artefact infused with an unusually high concentration of Weave, it's useless to me.

51.speaker: Gale
51.text: I know what I need, and I've spent too long trusting others to find it for me. It's time I shouldered my own burden, and let you shoulder yours. May we both get what we deserve.
51.context: NodeContext: Pissed off but holding back. Last line before leaving the party for good.

171.speaker: Gale
171.text: There's something I've been trying to tell you - I have a condition that requires me to consume potent magical artefacts.
171.context: NodeContext: In control byut impressing the urgency/seriousness of the moment on the player

72.speaker: Gale
72.text: I'm afraid my condition has escalated to the point we may be in some considerable danger. I must ask you to give me a suitable item. Immediately.
72.context: NodeContext: In control byut impressing the urgency/seriousness of the moment on the player

137.speaker: Gale
137.text: I'm afraid my condition has worsened to the point I cannot in good conscience stay in this company of ours. I need to leave, and seek an item to consume before it's too late.

110.speaker: Player
110.text: Why didn't you tell me? I would have helped you.

206.speaker: Gale
206.text: It's my own fault. Somehow I never found the right moment, and now it's far too late.
206.context: NodeContext: Annoyed, partly at the player, partly at himself

430.speaker: Player
430.text: Gods speed, Gale. I hope you find what you're looking for.

368.speaker: Gale
368.text: The Karsite Weave... I had no idea. Do you realise what this means?

310.speaker: Gale
310.text: The orb is no stray piece of ordinary magic. It is something entirely different - the nascent form of a new divine power.

321.speaker: Gale
321.text: Of course I couldn't control it. I was mortal. But once I reforge the crown, the power of a god will be mine to command. The orb will answer to me.
321.context: NodeContext: The pieces are beginning to fit - dawning excitement, imagine an unsettling glint entering Gale's eyes

401.speaker: Player
401.text: I'm not sure about all this. I thought the crown a simple artefact, but this Karsite Weave sounds... evil.

198.speaker: Gale
198.text: Evil is a reductive term, too often used to dismiss choices the observer lacks the imagination to understand.
198.context: NodeContext: Dismissing the argument off-hand - this is far bigger than such petty distinctions

407.speaker: Player
407.text: Wielding enough power to destroy a city? I like the sound of that.

146.speaker: Gale
146.text: So do I. Though I'm not sure that's the purpose I'd apply it to.

258.speaker: Player
258.text: What are the chances Mystra smites you before you get the chance?

123.speaker: Gale
123.text: Slim to none, I hope. Mystra has no right to prevent another ascending to the pantheon. Only Ao can decide that.

372.speaker: Player
372.text: You really expect me to believe you had no idea about the orb's true nature?

87.speaker: Gale
87.text: I knew it was powerful, of course, but I could hardly analyse something trapped within my own body.

121.speaker: Gale
121.text: Let me assure you - the Karsite Weave has no more inherent evil to it than a - a child in the womb, or an axe half-forged on the blacksmith's anvil.

436.speaker: Gale
436.text: It is a tool, ready to be shaped by its wielder. By me. And you know me to be someone of reasonably sound moral judgement, don't you?
436.context: NodeContext: Really wants a positive answer to this question

117.speaker: Player
117.text: We're usually inclined to agree on moral matters. That's good enough for me.

410.speaker: Player
410.text: Are you forgetting how you came into possession of the Karsite Weave? Your 'good intentions' could have detonated it.

304.speaker: Gale
304.text: But they didn't. I always thought it was a miracle that I survived, but I'm starting to wonder if there was more to it.

188.speaker: Player
188.text: It would make sense. Created by one powerful wizard, why not be drawn to another?

238.speaker: Gale
238.text: Precisely. What better person to wield Karsus' magic than one who is unafraid to pursue his ambition, gods and mortals be damned?

398.speaker: Player
398.text: Until recently, it was actively trying to kill you. I doubt it cares whose body it's in.

78.speaker: Gale
78.text: I don't think you're quite seeing what I'm seeing.

136.speaker: Player
136.text: You think this is your destiny?

129.speaker: Gale
129.text: Think about it - the Crown of Karsus, the Netherstones, the Karsite Weave - no more than a tadpole's breadth from being reunited.

308.speaker: Gale
308.text: This is my chance to get back everything that was taken from me. Everything Mystra denied me. And once I have it, I can forge a better world. Be a better god.

292.speaker: Gale
292.text: I want you to help me.

214.speaker: Player
214.text: No, Gale. This all sounds far too dangerous - Karsus' magic must be destroyed.

399.speaker: Gale
399.text: I thought you more ambitious than this. I see I was mistaken.

63.speaker: Gale
63.text: Very well. I'll drop the matter - for now.
63.context: NodeContext: Sees this isn't an argument he's going to win, but a hint that his plans might be unchanged.

366.speaker: Player
366.text: I'm right beside you. Time to make you a god.

249.speaker: Player
249.text: This is your decision to make, Gale. Not mine.

40.speaker: Gale
40.text: Well then - what more is there to discuss?

157.speaker: Gale
157.text: All we need to do is stay focused on the task at hand: defeating that elder brain. After that, you can leave the rest to me.

331.speaker: Player
331.text: You're turning coincidence into delusions of grandeur, Gale. Stop it.

141.speaker: Gale
141.text: I'm seeing exactly what's before my eyes. If you prefer to keep yours closed - that's up to you.

229.speaker: Player
229.text: Fine. If you truly believe this is the path you're meant for - I'll support you. I'll help you ascend to godhood.

140.speaker: Player
140.text: Morals be damned - this is an incredible opportunity. You must take it.

183.speaker: Gale
183.text: Gods, it's refreshing to share the company of someone who sees things the same way I do.

384.speaker: Gale
384.text: I was supposed to sacrifice myself to stop the Absolute - yet I don't think I could have gone through with it, in truth. And I'm glad that I didn't, given what has come to light.

386.speaker: Gale
386.text: I've been threatened with the sharp end of a dagger before, but never with such a monster as Orin holding the blade.

92.speaker: Gale
92.text: It certainly would have been a disappointment to spend so long resisting the instructions of my own god, only to die as the play thing of someone else's.

41.speaker: Player
41.text: Are you hurt? Did Orin harm you in any way?

52.speaker: Gale
52.text: I'm not sure I'll ever truly recover from the embarrassment of falling for her tricks, but physically - I'm absolutely fine. Rather well rested, as a matter of fact.

89.speaker: Gale
89.text: Whatever modicum of reason lurked in that warped mind of hers led her to spare me, rather than skewering my corpse over her temple door.

83.speaker: Player
83.text: You're lucky I bothered. I didn't think you were stupid enough to let yourself get taken like that.

255.speaker: Gale
255.text: And you're so sure you wouldn't have fallen for her tricks? She might have been a raving lunatic, but she knew exactly how to lower your defences.

295.speaker: Gale
295.text: She appeared to me as Elminster. Came to our camp while you were gone, telling me of a Netherese artefact he'd found. One he thought could turn the tide in our favour.

9.speaker: Gale
9.text: Part of me thought it was too good to be true, but the greater part decided to trust my old friend. I should have known it wouldn't be so easy.

185.speaker: Gale
185.text: I hope we never see Orin's like again. Mind flayers and Absolutists I can handle, but she was nothing but cruelty and carnage. Another whose god should go unworshipped.

73.speaker: Player
73.text: She made a grave mistake in taking you. One I was happy to punish her for.

6.speaker: Gale
6.text: I'm grateful that you did. Most would have abandoned me to my fate, rather than take on a Chosen of the god of Murder.

94.speaker: Player
94.text: Actually it's not Orin I wanted to talk to you about...

233.speaker: Gale
233.text: Glad to hear it. I'd rather leave that creature's memory firmly behind us. What do you need?
